newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ Dairy Board final payout rate 318 c/kg.
newsitem.headline: NZ Dairy Board final payout rate 318 c/kg.

text.p: The Dairy Board on Thursday announced a final price of 318c/kg of milk solids -- down 11.6 percent on last year's 360c/kg payout to farmers.
But the board effectively will add a further 3c/kg to its payout for the 1996-97 season by distributing tax credits to farmers.
For the average farmer in the main Waikato dairying region, each cent in the payout equates to more than $520 in farm income.
But the board said the 1997-98 milk price was expected to fall further -- in the range of 290c/kg-305c/kg, a drop of between 4 percent and 7.2 percent.
Board chairman Sir Dryden Spring said the slump of nearly 12 percent in payment for milk solids was in spite of a 12 percent increase in production, to a record 822 million kg for the season.
The board has previously said its optimal growth target for milk production is between 3 percent and 4 percent.

But the rise in the New Zealand dollar's value in key exchange rates against the U.S.dollar and the British pound sterling eroded the industry's earnings by $140 million -- equivalent of 17c/kg milk solids -- over the season.
Spring said the board expected further erosion of its earnings through adverse movements in the currency, as it was running out of room to delay those effects through hedging.
He did not expect any improvements in prices before the fourth quarter of 1997.
But there has been a cumulative increase in production of 20 percent over the past two years, and the board will have to sell more than 250,000 tonnes more product this season, compared with 1995-96.

"Despite the negative effects of currency and price movements, the board's added-value marketing in the consumer, food service and specialty ingredient business sectors generated an additional $100 million in revenues this year," Spring said.
"There is potential for market improvement later in the season," he said. If the trend of currency movements were to be reversed, the board would be in a good position to benefit.
"Given the market and currency outlook, the board proposes to set its advance price at 255c/kg," he said. This would be reviewed and added to through the year.
